title: 112_hr6102
content: The America's Small Business Tax Relief Act of 2012 is the short title of this Act. References in the Act are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The America's Small Business Tax Relief Act of 2012 includes provisions such as the permanent exclusion of gain on certain small business stock, 5-year carryback of general business credits, alternative minimum tax rules, reduction in recognition period for built-in gains tax, increased expensing limitations, special rules for long-term contract accounting, and allowance of deduction for health insurance. Sec. 9. Allowance of deduction for health insurance in computing self-employment taxes made permanent. SEC. 2. 100-PERCENT EXCLUSION OF GAIN ON CERTAIN SMALL BUSINESS STOCK MADE PERMANENT. The exclusion of gain on small business stock is now permanent for stock acquired after December 31, 2011. SEC. 3. 5-YEAR CARRYBACK OF GENERAL BUSINESS CREDITS OF ELIGIBLE SMALL BUSINESSES MADE PERMANENT. This allows eligible small businesses to carry back general business credits for 5 years. SEC. 4. Alternative minimum tax rules for general business credits of eligible small businesses made permanent. The amendment applies to credits determined in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. SEC. 5. Reduction in recognition period for built-in gains tax made permanent. SEC. 5. Reduction in recognition period for built-in gains tax made permanent. The recognition period for built-in gains tax is reduced from a 10-year period to a 5-year period. Conforming amendments are made to section 1374(d). Effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2011. In section 179, the limits for deductions are amended to $500,000 and $2,000,000. The provision for computer software placed in service between 2002 and 2013 is removed. Taxpayers can now revoke their election under section 179. Special rules for qualified real property are also included. Special rules for qualified real property under section 179(f) were amended to remove the restriction on years. These amendments will be effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. SEC. 7 amends section 460(c)(6) to have a recovery period of 7 years or less for long-term contract accounting. The amendment applies to property placed in service after December 31, 2011. SEC. 8 increases the deduction for start-up expenditures to $10,000 and $60,000 respectively, effective for amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2011. SEC. 9 makes the deduction for health insurance in computing self-employment taxes permanent, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2011.
